items.title: IBM swoops in to rescue UK Emergency Services Network after Motorola shown the door
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
With a near half-billion-pound price hike bringing contract value to £1.4B

IBM has secured a deal with the UK Home Office to supply user services for the troubled Emergency Service Network (ESN) upgrade, providing voice and data communications after Motorola withdrew from the project.…

items.title: Medusa ransomware group claims attack on UK's Gateshead Council
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
Pastes allegedly stolen documents on leak site with £600K demand

Another year and yet another UK local authority has been pwned by a ransomware crew. This time it's Gateshead Council in North East England at the hands of the Medusa group.…

items.title: Brit government contractor CloudKubed enters administration
items.author: Paul Kunert
items.summary:
Home Office, Department for Work and Pensions supplier in hands of FRP Advisory

A self-described specialist supplier of "transformational data and AI solutions" to the UK government has called in the administrative receivers.…

items.title: Tech support fill-in given no budget, no help, no training, and no empathy for his plight
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Fixed the problem anyway – with no approval for a purchase and no permission to use a device

On Call  When the weekend rolls around, nobody needs permission to do whatever they desire. Unless, of course, they're required to be available to support tech – a restriction we mark each week in On Call, the column that celebrates fine fixing feats achieved despite the footling of flummoxed fools.…

items.title: Microsoft eggheads say AI can never be made secure – after testing Redmond's own products
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
If you want a picture of the future, imagine your infosec team stamping on software forever

Microsoft brainiacs who probed the security of more than 100 of the software giant's own generative AI products came away with a sobering message: The models amplify existing security risks and create new ones.…

items.title: AWS adds 32-vCPU option and an easier on-ramp to its cloudy desktops
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Weirdly, this shows the weakness of hosted Windows with an admission about vidchats

Amazon Web Services has flicked the switch on a pair of workstation-grade cloud desktops that, ironically, highlight a problem with the tech.…

items.title: SpaceX resets ‘Days Since Starship Exploded’ counter to zero
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Test flight seven did better on the ground with a successful booster catch

SpaceX has again lost a Starship, after the seventh test flight of the spacecraft ended with a “rapid unscheduled disassembly”, but is nonetheless celebrating the mission as it ended with the second successful catch of its Super Heavy booster.…

items.title: Just as your LLM once again goes off the rails, Cisco, Nvidia are at the door smiling
items.author: Tobias Mann and Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Some of you have apparently already botched chatbots or allowed ‘shadow AI’ to creep in

Cisco and Nvidia have both recognized that as useful as today's AI may be, the technology can be equally unsafe and/or unreliable – and have delivered tools in an attempt to help address those weaknesses.…

items.title: GM parks claims that driver location data was given to insurers, pushing up premiums
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
We'll defo ask for permission next time, automaker tells FTC

General Motors on Thursday said that it has reached a settlement with the FTC "to address privacy concerns about our now-discontinued Smart Driver program."…

items.title: In farewell speech, Biden rails against the tech industrial complex, disinfo dismantling democracy
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
Welcome to a decade where the oligarchs are no longer silent in the shadows

US President Joe Biden gave his final address to the nation on Wednesday, and said America was visibly sliding into an oligopoly aided by a flood of online disinformation.…

items.title: Feds sue Southwest for chronic delays, unrealistic schedules
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Department of Transportation wants in on last-minute Biden administration action too

The Department of Transportation has joined the flurry of last-minute actions by the Biden administration with a lawsuit accusing Southwest Airlines of operating chronically delayed flights. …

items.title: Russia's Star Blizzard phishing crew caught targeting WhatsApp accounts
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
FSB cyberspies venture into a new app for espionage, Microsoft says

Star Blizzard, a prolific phishing crew backed by the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB), conducted a new campaign aiming to compromise WhatsApp accounts and gain access to their messages and data, according to Microsoft.…

items.title: TSMC plans to have 1.6nm chips in 'volume production' by 2026
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
You've got to spend money – like $36 billion+ – to make, er, AI chips

TSMC is bumping capital expenditure in 2025 to between $38 billion and $42 billion in anticipation of scooping up more chip manufacturing contracts in the field of AI processors.…

items.title: Enzo Biochem settles lawsuit over 2023 ransomware attack for $7.5M
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
That's in addition to the $4.5M fine paid to three state AGs last year

Enzo Biochem has settled a consolidated class-action lawsuit relating to its 2023 ransomware incident for $7.5 million.…

items.title: Anduril picks Ohio for 5 million square foot autonomous weapon factory
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
The hyperscale plant is designed to produce tens of thousands of AVs a year

Anduril has found a new home in Middle America with confirmation today that the defense tech maker plans to build its first hyperscale manufacturing facility in Columbus, Ohio. …

items.title: Raspberry Pi hands out prizes to all in the RP2350 Hacking Challenge
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Power-induced glitches, lasers, and electromagnetic fields are all tools of the trade

Raspberry Pi has given out prizes for extracting a secret value from the one-time-programmable (OTP) memory of the Raspberry Pi RP2350 microcontroller – awarding a pile of cash to all four entrants.…

items.title: Google reports halving code migration time with AI help
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
Chocolate Factory slurps own dogfood, sheds drudgery in specific areas

Google, which peddles AI software with as much giddy enthusiasm as Microsoft, reports dogfooding its own AI concoction and leaving the lab with a pleasant taste in its mouth.…

items.title: AI datacenters putting zero emissions promises out of reach
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Plus: Bit barns' demand for water, land, and power could breed 'growing opposition' from residents

The datacenter industry looks set for a turbulent 2025 as AI growth threatens to trump sustainability commitments and authorities are likely to see growing public hostility to new projects.…

items.title: Brits must prove their age on adult sites by July, says watchdog
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Regulator asks people to link their credit cards, mobile accounts, or face scans for smut use to protect kids

The UK's communications regulator has published guidance for website operators aimed at preventing under-18s from accessing pornographic content online via "highly effective age assurance" techniques.…

items.title: Debian 12.9 arrives, quickly followed by MX Linux 23.5
items.author: Liam Proven
items.summary:
The eighth point-release of Bookworm – yes, you read that right – and the latest MX with new Xfce

Debian 12.9 - the latest point-release of Debian "Bookworm" - emerged at the weekend and coming hot on its heels is one of the more interesting downstreams, MX Linux 23.5.…

items.title: Blue Origin reaches orbit with New Glenn, fumbles first-stage recovery
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Jeff Bezos' space company achieves milestone with payload delivered

Jeff Bezos joined the orbital elite with the launch of Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket this morning.…

items.title: Infoseccer: Private security biz let guard down, exposed 120K+ files
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
Assist Security’s client list includes fashion icons, critical infrastructure orgs

A London-based private security company allegedly left more than 120,000 files available online via an unsecured server, an infoseccer told The Register.…

items.title: Apple's interoperability efforts aren't meeting spirit or letter of EU law, advocacy groups argue
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
Free Software Foundation Europe and others urge European Commission to double down on DMA

Digital rights advocacy organizations contend that Apple has failed to comply with its interoperability obligations under the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA).…

items.title: UK government tech procurement lacks understanding, says watchdog
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
NAO report highlights £3B cost overruns and 29 years of cumulative delays in IT projects

UK government plans its technology purchases with limited assessment of technical feasibility, according to a spending watchdog's analysis of the £14-billion-a-year procurement of digital services.…

items.title: India becomes just fourth country to dock satellites in orbit
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
As the ESA celebrates planned break-up of its solar blotter-spotter

India’s Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has successfully docked a pair of satellites, making the nation the fourth to achieve the feat.…

items.title: US adds Chinese RISC-V player that TSMC suspected of helping build Huawei GPUs to risky company register
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Sophgo scores a place on Entity List, Indian nuclear boffins taken off

Chinese chip designer Sophgo, a suspected supplier of AI silicon to Huawei, has been added to the USA’s “Entity List” of orgs felt to represent a national security risk and therefore prohibited from working with American companies unless a license is issued to allow such dealings.…

items.title: Parallels brings back the magic that was waiting seven minutes for Windows to boot
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
In a preview of x86_64 VMs running on Apple silicon, so it’s excusable for now

Desktop hypervisor specialist Parallels has released an early technology preview of code that allows virtual machines running OSes coded for the x86_64 architecture, such as Microsoft Windows, to run on Apple’s Arm-powered silicon.…

items.title: Nvidia shovels $500M into Israeli boffinry supercomputer
items.author: Tobias Mann
items.summary:
System to feature hundreds of liquid-cooled Blackwell systems

Nvidia is constructing a 30-megawatt research-and-development supercomputer stuffed with its latest-generation Blackwell GPUs in northern Israel at an estimated cost of half a billion dollars.…

items.title: GoDaddy slapped with wet lettuce for years of lax security and 'several major breaches'
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
Watchdog alleged it had no SIEM or MFA, orders rapid adoption of basic infosec tools

GoDaddy has failed to protect its web-hosting platform with even basic infosec tools and practices since 2018, according to the FTC, but the internet giant won’t face any immediate consequences for its many alleged acts of omission.…

items.title: DJI loosens flight restrictions, decides to trust operators to follow FAA rules
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Right after one of its drones crashed into an aircraft fighting California wildfires? Great timing

Drone maker DJI has decided to scale back its geofencing restrictions, meaning its software won't automatically stop operators from flying into areas flagged as no-fly zones. …

items.title: Oh, Deere! FTC sues tractor maker, alleging decades of monopolized repairs
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Incoming Trump-picked watchdog boss dissents, calls suit 'hasty' and 'deeply imprudent,' so will it stick?

Updated  America's top consumer watchdog has sued tractor maker John Deere for monopolizing tech repair services for its machinery, though whether the lawsuit will survive the pending presidential transition remains to be seen. …

items.title: China's Salt Typhoon spies spotted on US govt networks before telcos, CISA boss says
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
We are only seeing 'the tip of the iceberg,' Easterly warns

Beijing's Salt Typhoon cyberspies had been seen in US government networks before telcos discovered the same foreign intruders in their own systems, according to CISA boss Jen Easterly.…

items.title: IT job market is still shrinking but not as quickly as last year
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Half the number of roles axed, and yes – you can keep blaming AI

The IT jobs market has shrunk for a second year in a row, says tech consultancy Janco Associates, but at least things weren't as bad in 2024 as they were in 2023.…

items.title: Even modest makeup can thwart facial recognition
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
You may not need to go full Juggalo for the sake of privacy

Researchers at cyber-defense contractor PeopleTec have found that facial-recognition algorithms' focus on specific areas of the face opens the door to subtler surveillance avoidance strategies.…

items.title: Nvidia plots Quantum Day at GTC 2025 – for tech it called a distant dream
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Don't believe the hype? GPU maker jumps on the bandwagon anyway

A week after Nvidia chief Jensen Huang demolished the market valuations of listed quantum computing brands by saying the technology is 20 years away from being useful, the GPU maker has confirmed it is hosting a quantum computing day.…

items.title: Windows Patch Tuesday hits snag with Citrix software, workarounds published
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Microsoft starts 2025 as it hopefully doesn't mean to go on

Devices that have Citrix's Session Recording software installed are having problems completing this month's Microsoft Patch Tuesday update, which includes important fixes.…

items.title: 'Savvy' shortcuts produce near-instant speech-to-speech translation of 36 languages
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
Babel Fish like ML model emerges after training on 4.5 million hours of multilingual spoken audio

Meta has developed a machine learning model its researchers claim offers near-instant speech-to-speech translation between around 36 languages.…

items.title: AI frenzy continues as Macquarie commits up to $5B for Applied Digital datacenters
items.author: Tobias Mann
items.summary:
Bubble? What bubble?

Fears of an AI bubble have yet to scare off venture capitalists and private equity firms from pumping billions of dollars into the GPU-packed datacenters at the heart of the machine-learning craze.…

items.title: Crypto klepto North Korea stole $659M over just 5 heists last year
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
US, Japan, South Korea vow to intensify counter efforts

North Korean blockchain bandits stole more than half a billion dollars in cryptocurrency in 2024 alone, the US, Japan, and South Korea say.…

items.title: Megan, AI recruiting agent, is on the job, giving bosses fewer reasons to hire in HR
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
She doesn't feel pity, remorse, or fear, but she'll craft a polite email message as she turns you down

Interview  Mega HR, a Florida-based human resources startup, today launched an AI agent service called Megan that the biz claims can automate most recruiting and hiring tasks while improving communication with job applicants.…

items.title: Enterprises in for a shock when they realize power and cooling demands of AI
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Energy consumption set to become a key performance indicator by 2027

Most businesses rushing to adopt AI are unprepared for the energy demands it'll place on their infrastructure, and few have a handle on the power consumption of AI systems or the implications for their datacenters.…

items.title: Shove your office mandates, people still prefer working from home
items.author: Paul Kunert
items.summary:
Threat to quit still preferred to commuting on packed public transport

Years after the pandemic reshaped working practices across the world, many staff are still resisting corporate efforts to get them to return to the office preferring instead to quit in favor of a more flexible employer.…

items.title: Four plead guilty in US government tech procurement fraud case
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
Scheme involving bribes, bid rigging and insider info may have cost US taxpayers $1.3M

Four defendants have pleaded guilty in a US government IT procurement fraud case, which prosecutors claim has cost taxpayers at least $1.3 million in losses.…

items.title: SpaceX launches 2 lunar landers on path to the Moon
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Blue Ghost's first time, and second time lucky for Japanese company ispace?

SpaceX has successfully completed the 100th launch of a Falcon rocket from pad 39A and sent two landers on their way to the Moon.…

items.title: British tribunal claim aims to take a bite out of Apple over App Store fees
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Collective Proceedings Order seeks £1.5B from iGiant

Seven weeks of court action began this week as a case over alleged breaches of competition law by Apple is heard at the UK's Competition Appeal Tribunal (CAT).…

items.title: UK businesses eye AI as the cheaper, non-whining alternative to actual staff
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Rising costs blamed, although any excuse to do more with less

British companies are looking to AI as a way of cutting investment in staff, according to new research.…

items.title: Foundation model for tabular data slashes training from hours to seconds
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
Good ol' spreadsheet data could benefit from 'revolutionary' approach to ML inferences

Move over ChatGPT and DALL-E: Spreadsheet data is getting its own foundation machine learning model, allowing users to immediately make inferences about new data points for data sets with up to 10,000 rows and 500 columns.…

items.title: Microsoft’s latest on-prem Azure is for apps you don’t want in the cloud, but will manage from it
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Azure Local is about hybrid management, not hybrid resource pools, and is catching up with virtual rivals

Microsoft’s latest on-prem Azure offering is more about unified management than hybrid cloud as an enabler of elasticity or flexible resource pools.…

items.title: Boeing going backwards as production’s slowing and woes keep flowing
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
No such problems at Airbus, which cruised at a high level and shipped almost two planes a day last year

Beleaguered aerospace outfit Boeing has revealed how many commercial aircraft it shipped in 2024, and the news isn’t good.…

items.title: Intel Capital next into the chip giant's trebuchet, to be shot as far over the wall as possible
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
This'll be good for you, don't you worry, CFO tells venture fund while pulling back the sling

Stricken silicon giant Intel has decided it doesn’t want to be the sole investor in its venture capital operation, so will spin it out for others to plow money into.…
